tit.e: Traditional vegetables of Kyo (another name for Kyoto Prefecture)
Traditional vegetables of Kyo (another name for Kyoto Prefecture)
tit.cmt: タイトルのため単語の頭文字を大文字にしました。(another name for Kyoto Prefecture)→次文に移動

sen.j: 京の伝統野菜（きょうのでんとうやさい）とは、京都府によって認定された野菜の品目の事で、1987年（昭和62年）の認定開始以来、現在まで41品目の野菜が認定されており、その中には、京の伝統野菜に準じる野菜の品目や、既に絶滅しまった野菜の品目も含まれる。
sen.e: Traditional vegetables of Kyo refers to the crops of vegetables that have been certified by the Kyoto Prefecture since the certification began in 1987, and 41 crops of vegetables have been certified so far, including those that are almost equivalent to traditional vegetables of Kyo, and those that are already extinct.
sen.cmt: 「絶滅しまった」→「絶滅してしまった」
sen.e: Traditional vegetables of Kyo refers to the crops of vegetables that have been certified by the Kyoto Prefecture since the certification began in 1987, and 41 crops of vegetables have been certified so far, including those that are almost equivalent to traditional vegetables of Kyo, and those that are already extinct.

Traditional vegetables of Kyo (another name for Kyoto Prefecture) refers to the crops of vegetables that have been certified by the Kyoto Prefecture since the certification began in 1987, and 41 crops of vegetables have been certified so far, including those that are almost equivalent to traditional vegetables of Kyo, and those that are already extinct.
sen.cmt: Kyo (another name for Kyoto Prefecture) としました。

sen.j: 京都に都が置かれていた明治維新以前からの生産されていた歴史を有する野菜の品目。
sen.e: Crops of vegetables that have a history of having been produced even before the Meiji Restoration, when the government was located in Kyoto City.
Crops of vegetables that have a history of having been produced even before the Meiji Restoration, when the government was located in Kyoto City.
Crops of vegetables that have a history of having been produced even before the Meiji Restoration, when the government was located in Kyoto City.

sen.j: 京都市域のみならず、京都府内全域で生産されている野菜の品目。
sen.e: Crops of vegetables that are produced not only in Kyoto City but also those produced throughout Kyoto Prefecture.
Crops of vegetables that are produced not only in Kyoto City but also those produced throughout Kyoto Prefecture.
Crops of vegetables that are produced not only in Kyoto City but also those produced throughout Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 筍を含む。
sen.e: Includes bamboo shoots.
Includes bamboo shoots.
Includes bamboo shoots.

sen.j: キノコ類、シダ類（ぜんまい、わらび等）を除く。
sen.e: Excludes mushrooms and ferns (eg. royal ferns and brackens).
Excludes mushrooms and ferns (eg. royal ferns and brackens).
Excludes mushrooms and ferns (eg. royal ferns and brackens).

sen.j: 種の保存の為にのみ栽培されている野菜の品目。
sen.e: Crops of vegetables that are grown for the sole purpose of seed preservation;
Crops of vegetables that are grown for the sole purpose of seed preservation;
Crops of vegetables that are grown for the sole purpose of seed preservation.

sen.j: 又は、栽培されてないものの種が保存されている野菜の品目。
sen.e: or crops of vegetables that are no longer cultivated but whose seeds are preserved;
or crops of vegetables that are no longer cultivated but whose seeds are preserved;
Or crops of vegetables that are no longer cultivated but whose seeds are preserved.
sen.cmt: 文頭の頭文字を大文字に、および; →. に変更

sen.j: 及び絶滅した野菜の品目を含む。
sen.e: and includes crops of vegetables that are extinct.
and includes crops of vegetables that are extinct.
And includes crops of vegetables that are extinct.
sen.cmt: 文頭の頭文字を大文字に変更

tit.e: A list of traditional vegetables of Kyo
A list of traditional vegetables of Kyo
A List of Traditional Vegetables of Kyo
tit.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更
頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 京都市北区鷹峯が原産で元禄（1688）の頃から栽培されていたと言われる。
sen.e: Karami daikon, which is originated in Takagamiine, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, is said to have been cultivated since the Genroku era (1688).
Karami daikon, which is originated in Takagamiine, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, is said to have been cultivated since the Genroku era (1688).
Karami daikon, which is originated in Takagamine, Kita Ward, Kyoto City, is said to have been cultivated since the Genroku era (1688).

sen.j: 小蕪に似ているが、れっきとした大根である。
sen.e: Although it resembles small turnip, it is genuine daikon.
Although it resembles a small turnip, it is genuine daikon.
Although it resembles a small turnip, it is genuine daikon.

sen.j: 根に強い辛味がある、蕎麦の薬味等に使われる。
sen.e: The Karami daikon has a strong pungency in the root; and it is used for soba (buckwheat noodle) seasoning, among other purposes.
The Karami daikon has a strong pungency in the root; and is used for soba (buckwheat noodle) seasoning, among other purposes.
The Karami daikon has a strong pungency in the root; and is used for soba (buckwheat noodle) seasoning, among other purposes.

sen.j: 直径3～5cmくらいで、丸型。
sen.e: It has a diameter of approximately three to five centimeters, and has a round shape.
It has a diameter of approximately three to five centimeters, and has a round shape.
It has a diameter of approximately three to five centimeters, and has a round shape.

sen.j: 江戸時代の文化・文政（1804～29）の頃、今は絶滅した「郡大根」の変異種として生まれたと伝えられる。
sen.e: Aomi daikon is said to be a mutant product of "Kori daikon" (daikon produced in Goku-Kori cho (a town in Kyoto City)), which is already extinct, during the Bunka-Bunsei era of the Edo period.
Aomi daikon is said to be a mutant product of "Kori daikon" (daikon produced in Goku-Kori cho (a town in Kyoto City)), which is already extinct, during the Bunka-Bunsei era of the Edo period.

Aomi daikon is said to be a mutant product of 'Kori daikon' (daikon produced in Goku-Kori cho, a town in Kyoto City), which is already extinct, during the Bunka-Bunsei eras (1804 - 1829) of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: （1804～29）を訳出、era→erasに修正、シングルクォーテーションに変更、カッコ内の補足を一部修正

sen.j: 直径1～1.5cm、長さ12～15cmの細い大根で、根は1、2回曲がって独特な形になる。
sen.e: It has a diameter of one to one and a half centimeter, and has a thin shape that is twelve to fifteen centimeters long; and its root bends once or twice, resulting in a unique shape.
It has a diameter of one to one and a half centimeters, and has a thin shape that is twelve to fifteen centimeters long; and its root bends once or twice, resulting in a unique shape.
It has a diameter of one to one and a half centimeters, and has a thin shape that is twelve to fifteen centimeters long; and its root bends once or twice, resulting in a unique shape.

sen.j: 地上に出る首の部分が緑色をしている為「青味だいこん」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: It is called "Aomi daikon" due to the green color of its neck, which shows above the ground.
It is called "Aomi daikon" due to the green color of its neck, which sticks out above the ground.
It is called 'Aomi daikon' due to the green color of its neck, which sticks out above the ground.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更

sen.j: 青味大根は昔からご祝儀用に欠かせないもので、吸い物の具や、青味の部分がキュウリの代用、刺身のつまに利用され、また漬物用として珍重された。
sen.e: For a long time, Aomi daikon has been an indispensable crop for ceremonial occasions; it has been used as an ingredient of clear soup, and the green portion as substitute for cucumbers or side green of sashimi, and has been a much-prized item of Japanese pickles.

For a long time, Aomi daikon has been an indispensable crop for ceremonial occasions; it has been used as an ingredient in clear soup, and the green portion as substitute for cucumbers or side green of sashimi, and has been a much-prized item of Japanese pickles.

For a long time, Aomi daikon has been an indispensable crop for ceremonial occasions; it has been used as an ingredient in clear soup, and the green portion as substitute for cucumbers or side green of sashimi, and has been a much-prized item of tsukemono (Japanese pickled vegetables).
sen.cmt: "Japanese pickles" -> "tsukemono (Japanese pickled vegetables)" に変更しました。

sen.j: 8月下旬～9月上旬に種播きし、11月～1月末に収穫。
sen.e: Its seeds are sown during late August and early September, and harvested during November and the end of January.
Its seeds are sown during late August and early September, and harvested during November and the end of January.
Its seeds are sown during late August and early September, and harvested during November and the end of January.

sen.j: 京都市特産そ菜保存委託事業として、市内の3戸の農家が栽培を続け、種の自家採種をおこなっている。
sen.e: Three farmhouses in the city keep up the cultivation and in-house seed production as a commissioned business for preservation of specialty vegetables of Kyoto Prefecture.
Three farmhouses in the city keep up the cultivation and in-house seed production as a commissioned business for preservation of specialty vegetables of Kyoto Prefecture.
Three farmhouses in the city keep up the cultivation and in-house seed production as a commissioned business for preservation of specialty vegetables of Kyoto City.

tit.e: Tokinashi daikon (daikon named after its nature of being produced irrespective of seasons (toki))
Tokinashi daikon (daikon named after its nature of being produced irrespective of seasons (toki))
Tokinashi daikon (daikon named after its nature of being produced irrespective of seasons (toki))

sen.j: 文政の初年度（1810から1820）紀伊郡東九条村（現在の南区東九条）の小山藤七という人が、当時極晩生種であった大根の種を得て、「藤七大根」という名で種を販売したのが源であるといわれている。
sen.e: The story behind the origin of Tokinashi daikon is that in the first year of the Bunsei era (1810 - 1820), a man named Toshichi KOYAMA from Higashikujo village, Kii district (present-day Higashikujo, Minami Ward) obtained seeds of the daikon which was an extremely late variety at the time, and sold them under the name "Toshichi-daikon".

The story behind the origin of Tokinashi daikon is that in the first year of the Bunsei era (1810 - 1820), a man named Toshichi KOYAMA from Higashikujo village, Kii district (present-day Higashikujo, Minami Ward) obtained extremely late variety of daikon seed at the time, and sold them under the name "Toshichi-daikon".

The story behind the origin of Tokinashi daikon is that in the first year of the Bunsei era (1810 - 1820), a man named Toshichi KOYAMA from Higashikujo village, Kii district (present-day Higashikujo, Minami Ward) obtained extremely late variety of daikon seed at the time, and sold them under the name 'Toshichi-daikon.'
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、ピリオドの位置を移動

sen.j: 当時の大根は堀入で地上部に根部が露出する事なく、葉は著しく濃緑色で欠刻を有し、現在の時無大根に比べると、極めて晩生種であったと思われる。
sen.e: The daikon of the time had no above-ground exposure, without any root showing above the ground, with significantly dark green leaves that have slits; and it is assumed that they were of an exceptionally late variety compared to the present-day Tokinashi daikon.

The daikon of the time had no above-ground exposure, without any root showing above the ground, with significantly dark green leaves that have slits; and it is assumed that they were of an exceptionally late variety compared to the present-day Tokinashi daikon.

The daikon of the time had no above-ground exposure, without any root showing above the ground, with significantly dark green leaves that have slits; and it is assumed that they were of an exceptionally late variety compared to the present-day Tokinashi daikon.

sen.j: 葉は淡青緑色、深い切れこみがある直立性で、中肋の細かいのが特徴で、根部は先端が細まった尖円筒形をしており、太さ直径6～8cm、長さ45cm程である。
sen.e: Tokinashi daikon's leaves are characterized by their turquoise color, the straightness with deep slits, and fine midribs; the root has a cusp cylinder shape with a diameter of six to eight centimeters, and is approximately forty-five centimeters long.

Tokinashi daikon's leaves are characterized by their turquoise color, the straightness with deep slits, and fine midribs; the root has a cusp cylinder shape with a diameter of six to eight centimeters, and is approximately forty-five centimeters long.

Tokinashi daikon's leaves are characterized by their turquoise color, the straightness with deep slits, and fine midribs; the root has a cusp cylinder shape with a diameter of six to eight centimeters, and is approximately forty-five centimeters long.

tit.e: Momoyama (name of an area in Kyoto City) daikon
tit.cmt: 「Momoyama (name of an area in Kyoto City)」←ご確認下さい。
tit.e: Momoyama (name of an area in Kyoto City) daikon
Momoyama (name of an area in Kyoto City) daikon

sen.j: 起源は定かでないが滋賀県と云われている。
sen.e: The origin is said to be Shiga Prefecture although this is not certain.
The origin is said to be Shiga Prefecture although this is not certain.
The origin is said to be Shiga Prefecture although this is not certain.

sen.j: 伊吹山大根を大亀谷に移して栽培されたと言われ、肉質が緻密で漬け物栽培用として作られていたが、現在は需要が激減し種子保存用のみと言う。
sen.e: Momoyama daikon is said to have been cultivated by transferring Ibukiyama (a mountain lying between Shiga Prefecture and Gifu Prefecture as a boundary) daikon to Okamedani (name of an area in Kyoto City), and because of its dense flesh it was cultivated for pickle usage, but it is currently cultivated for the sole purpose of seed preservation due to a sharp decrease in demand.
sen.cmt: 「Okamedani (name of an area in Kyoto City)」←ご確認下さい。
sen.e: Momoyama daikon is said to have been cultivated by transferring Ibukiyama (a mountain lying between Shiga Prefecture and Gifu Prefecture as a boundary) daikon to Okamedani (name of an area in Kyoto City), and because of its dense flesh it was cultivated for pickle usage, but it is currently cultivated for the sole purpose of seed preservation due to a sharp decrease in demand.

Momoyama daikon is said to have been cultivated by transferring Ibukiyama (a mountain lying between Shiga Prefecture and Gifu Prefecture as a boundary) daikon to Okamedani (name of an area in Kyoto City), and because of its dense flesh it was cultivated for pickle usage, but it is currently cultivated for the sole purpose of seed preservation due to a sharp decrease in demand.

tit.cmt: Shogoin daikonとし、(name of a temple)削除

sen.j: 聖護院大根は蕪のような丸い大根で、京都の冬には欠かせ無い野菜である。
sen.e: Shogo-in daikon has a round shape like that of a turnip, and it is an essential crop in Kyoto during winter.
Shogo-in daikon has a round shape like that of a turnip, and it is an essential crop in Kyoto during winter.
Shogoin daikon has a round shape like that of a turnip, and it is an essential crop in Kyoto during winter.

sen.j: 煮ると大変、軟らかく、味が染み込みやすく、通常の大根と比べると、倍以上の値の高級品である。
sen.e: It becomes very soft when boiled and easily absorbs the soup; thus it is a quality merchandise costing twice as much as ordinary daikon or even higher.
It becomes very soft when boiled and easily absorbs the soup; thus it is a quality merchandise costing twice as much as ordinary daikon or even higher.
It becomes very soft when boiled and easily absorbs the soup; thus it is a quality merchandise costing twice as much as ordinary daikon or even higher.

sen.j: 初めは、普通の長いダイコンで、誕生地は京都市東部の、左京区聖護院。
sen.e: At first it was ordinary, long daikon, its place of birth being Shogo-in temple, Sakyo Ward in eastern Kyoto City.
At first it was ordinary, long daikon, its place of birth being Shogo-in temple, Sakyo Ward in eastern Kyoto City.
At first it was ordinary, long daikon, its place of birth being Shogoin, Sakyo Ward in eastern Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: 聖護院→ここでは寺院名でなく地名として言及されていると思われます。Shogo-in Temple→Shogoinとしました。(参考: http://dictionary.goo.ne.jp/leaf/jn/93505/m0u/%E8%81%96/)

sen.j: 江戸時代後期の文政年間、聖護院の東の黒谷という場所に金戒光明寺という寺院が在り、この寺院に尾張から大根が奉納され、聖護院の農家がその大根を貰いうけ、何年も育てていると、何故か丸くなってしまったと言う。
sen.e: During the Bunsei era in the latter part of the Edo period, this daikon was given to Konkaikomyo-ji temple in Kurotani district in the east of Shogo-in temple, as an offering from Owari Province; when a farmer in Shogo-in temple was given the daikon and grew it for years, the shape somehow changed to a round shape.

During the Bunsei era in the latter part of the Edo period, this daikon was given to Konkaikomyo-ji temple in Kurotani district in the east of Shogo-in temple, as an offering from Owari Province; when a farmer in Shogo-in temple was given the daikon and grew it for years, the shape somehow changed to a round shape.

During the Bunsei era in the latter part of the Edo period, this daikon was given to Konkaikomyo-ji Temple in Kurotani district in the east of Shogoin district, as an offering from Owari Province; when a farmer in Shogoin district was given the daikon and grew it for years, the shape somehow changed to a round shape.
sen.cmt: Shogo-in Temple→Shogoin districtとし、templeの頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: これが聖護院大根である。
sen.e: This is how Shogo-in daikon came about.
This is how Shogo-in daikon came about.
This is how Shogoin daikon came about.

tit.e: Shishigatani (name of an area in Kyoto City) pumpkin
tit.cmt: 「Shishigatani (name of an area in Kyoto City)」←ご確認下さい。
tit.e: Shishigatani (name of an area in Kyoto City) pumpkin
Shishigatani (name of an area in Kyoto City) pumpkin

sen.j: 鹿ヶ谷南瓜は、昔から京都では、「おかぼ」と呼ばれていて、 文化 (元号)年間（1804～1818)の頃、東山 (京都府)の百姓が、津軽に旅をした時、南瓜を持ち帰り、鹿ケ谷に住む他の百姓にその南瓜をやった所、百姓達は早速、自分の畑に植えて、栽培したのが始まりと云われる。
sen.e: Shishigatani pumpkin has long been called "okabo" in Kyoto; During the Bunka era (1804 - 1818), a farmer in Higashiyama (in Kyoto Prefecture) made a trip to Tsugaru (name of a region in eastern Aomori Prefecture) and brought back pumpkins with him and gave them to other farmers in Shishigatani; the farmers planted the pumpkins in their fields right away and this is said to be the start of the cultivation.

Shishigatani pumpkin has long been called "okabo" in Kyoto; During the Bunka era (1804 - 1818), a farmer in Higashiyama (in Kyoto Prefecture) made a trip to Tsugaru (name of a region in eastern Aomori Prefecture) and brought back pumpkins with him and gave them to other farmers in Shishigatani; the farmers planted the pumpkins in their fields right away and this is said to be the start of their cultivation.

Shishigatani pumpkin has long been called 'okabo' in Kyoto; during the Bunka era (1804 - 1818), a farmer in Higashiyama (in Kyoto Prefecture) made a trip to Tsugaru (name of a region in eastern Aomori Prefecture) and brought back pumpkins with him and gave them to other farmers in Shishigatani; the farmers planted the pumpkins in their fields right away and this is said to be the start of their cultivation.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、During→duringに修正

sen.j: 鹿ケ谷かぼちゃは、一般の南瓜と比べて、栄養価が高いのが特徴の瓢箪に似た形状の南瓜である。
sen.e: Shishigata pumpkin is characterized by being more nutritious compared to ordinary pumpkins, and it looks like gourd.
Shishigata pumpkin is characterized by being more nutritious compared to ordinary pumpkins, and it looks like gourd.
Shishigata pumpkin is characterized by being more nutritious compared to ordinary pumpkins, and it looks like gourd.

tit.e: Ebiimo (sweet potatoes in the form of a shrimp)
Ebiimo (sweet potatoes in the form of a shrimp)
Ebiimo (sweet potatoes in the form of a shrimp)

sen.j: 海老芋は、享保（1716～1736）の頃、東山 (京都府)の1つ、華頂山麓にある青蓮院の門跡が、九州を巡行し、海老のような縞模様の芋を持ち帰り、その芋を仕えていた平野権太夫が拝領して、同じ華頂山西側の小丘である円山の地で栽培したところ、海老のような反りと縞模様をもった質の良い芋ができたので、その姿から、海老芋と名付けられたと云われている。
sen.e: It is said that during the Kyoho era (1716 - 1736), the head monk of Sorei-in temple at the base of Mount Kachozan, one of Higashiyama mountains (in Kyoto Prefecture), brought back with him striped potatoes shaped like shrimp when he returned from his travel over Kyushu; the potatoes were given to Gondayu HIRANO who was serving the monk, and when the potatoes were cultivated in the land of Maruyama, which is a hillock on the western side of the Mount Kachozan, the potatoes harvested were of good quality and had warpage and stripe patterns like those of shrimp, and were thus given the name ebiimo.

It is said that during the Kyoho era (1716 - 1736), the head monk of Sorei-in temple at the base of Mount Kachozan, one of Higashiyama mountains (in Kyoto Prefecture), brought back with him striped potatoes shaped like shrimp \ when he returned from his travel over Kyushu; the potatoes were given to Gondayu HIRANO who served the monk, and when the potatoes were cultivated in the land of Maruyama, which is a hillock on the western side of the Mount Kachozan, the potatoes harvested were of excellent quality and had warpage and stripe patterns like those of shrimp, and thus were given the name ebiimo.

It is said that during the Kyoho era (1716 - 1736), the head monk of Shoren-in Temple at the base of Mt. Kacho, one of Higashiyama mountain range (in Kyoto Prefecture), brought back with him striped potatoes shaped like shrimp when he returned from his travel over Kyushu; the potatoes were given to Gondayu HIRANO who served the monk, and when the potatoes were cultivated in the land of Maruyama, which is a hillock on the western side of the Mt. Kacho, the potatoes harvested were of excellent quality and had warpage and stripe patterns like those of shrimp, and thus were given the name ebiimo.
sen.cmt: "\"削除、Sorei-in temple→Shoren-in Temple、Mount Kachozan→Mt. Kachoに修正、Higashiyama mountains→Higashiyama mountain rangeとしました。

sen.j: 芋としては、比較的原始的な性質を残している品種で、肉質は粉質で、粘り気に富み、よく締まった風味を持つ。
sen.e: As potatoes, they are of a variety which retains comparatively primitive characteristics, have flesh which is powdery and very sticky, and have a pronounced flavor.
As potatoes, they are of a variety which retain comparatively primitive characteristics, have flesh which is powdery and very sticky, and have a pronounced flavor.
As potatoes, they are of a variety which retain comparatively primitive characteristics, have flesh which is powdery and very sticky, and have a pronounced flavor.

sen.j: 葉柄はサトイモ として食される。
sen.e: The leafstalks are eaten as aroid.
The leafstalks are eaten as aroid.
The leafstalks are eaten as aroid.

sen.j: 京野菜としての人気の高まりから、京都以外に各地でも栽培されている。
sen.e: Due to its growing popularity as a traditional vegetable of Kyoto, ebiimo is grown in various regions other than Kyoto.
Due to its growing popularity as a traditional vegetable of Kyoto, ebiimo is grown in various regions other than Kyoto.
Due to its growing popularity as a traditional vegetable of Kyoto, ebiimo is grown in various regions other than Kyoto.

sen.j: 煮物などに利用される。
sen.e: Ebiimo is used in boiled food and other dishes.
Ebiimo is used in boiled food and other dishes.
Ebiimo is used in boiled food and other dishes.
